awd_titl_txt: CIF21 DIBBs: EI: mProv: Provence-Based Data Analytics Cyberinfrastructure for High-frequency Mobile Sensor Data
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses a rapidly growing opportunity: the ability of the research community to use high-frequency mobile sensor data.  Mobile sensors (embedded in phones, vehicles, wearables, and the environment) continuously capture data in great detail, and have the potential to address problems in a range of scientific and engineering domains.  This effort focuses upon a specific case -- health data -- that builds upon several capabilities developed in National Institutes of Health (NIH) sponsored projects for assembling and analyzing health data collected through mobile sensors and apps.  Improvements to the usefulness of extremely noisy, distributed data can serve many communities, and the components are extensible outside the human health domain.  

Mobile sensors present a distinct set of data challenges: the data quantity and quality fluctuate, and uncertainty can be high.  Establishing provenance on such noisy data is a challenge, and there are limitations on access to data from human subjects.  This project addresses several of the distinctive challenges associated with mobile sensor data.   Variability is addressed by providing detailed annotation with metadata (such as provenance and quality), and by providing facilities for context-specific reasoning about the metadata.  The system captures provenance metadata along with data in a stream, and propagates this information alongside derived data from one stage to the next.  This creates cyberinfrastructure that makes it possible to 'replay' mobile device data with different configurations, to comparatively benchmark two algorithms or to diagnose erroneous output.  The project builds upon the capabilities and success of the NIH-funded Center of Excellence in Mobile Sensor Data to Knowledge (MD2K), which provides an open-source cyberinfrastructure enabling the collection, curation, analysis, visualization, and interpretation of high-frequency mobile sensor data.  Conducting research with mobile sensor data collected by others continues to be challenging; this project develops a companion open-source provenance cyberinfrastructure, facilitating the sharing of the mobile sensor data itself.  Results include metadata standards, interfaces, and runtime support for annotating data streams with the source (sensor, location, sampling rate, continuous or episodic), semantics of output (number, probability, class), provenance (features, rules for decision), and validation (specificity, sensitivity, benchmark used).  The infrastructure accommodates a wide variety of data types and enables data discovery, analytics, visualization, integration, and validation by third party researchers. The project improves the ability of the wider scientific and engineering community to use mobile sensing systems and metadata, and it also has immediate, tangible societal benefits in health and wellness.  

This award by the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Division is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering (Division of Computer and Network Systems, and Division of Information and Intelligent Systems).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
To overcome major hurdles in using high-frequency mobile sensor data collected in users’ natural environment for computational modeling of human health and behavior, the mProv project has developed novel methods, technologies, open-source libraries, and open datasets towards its goals. They included techniques to integrate metadata and provenance to mobile streaming data and datastreams derived from them, and propagating them throughout the data processing layers in order to enable reasoning about uncertainty and variability; runtime infrastructure and APIs for efficient sensor data acquisition and replay (integrated with human data capture), and mechanisms for managing privacy policies. 

It developed a provenance cyberinfrastructure called PennProv for automatic capture, tracking, and storing of provenance for both graph database (Neo4J) and traditional relational database (PostgreSQL) that is tamper-resistant. PennProv supports dynamic metadata that captures policies, data quality settings, and provenance, ensuring they can be efficiently captured and propagated in a mobile device setting. It provides a full Provenance API that captures relationships between data items and processing steps – for both coarse-grained (file-to-file or object-to-object) processing as well as fine-grained (record-to-record) processing steps, in streaming as well as batch tasks. PennProv also includes a provenance tracking reference model for capturing fine-grained relationships between windowed stream inputs and outputs. It provides novel algebraic operators, algorithms, and search techniques for describing in a declarative fashion the core logic in algorithms that do approximate matching, user-defined aggregation, and user-defined content extraction from objects, augment missing or coarse-grained provenance information, and replay and reason about previously archived computational pipelines. PennProv can be used to see where (and for which inputs) alternative code versions produce different outputs, to infer parameter settings that were missing from the captured provenance, and to trace the input records responsible for particular results. PennProv has been designed to link effectively with Apache Spark and Cerebral Cortex, as well as a data platform for sharing device data called PennSieve.  It also has APIs that can be called from virtually any programming environment.  PennProv has also developed foundational techniques for compressing provenance graphs.

To automatically assess and annotate streaming data with dynamic data quality, the project developed the mDebugger tool for physiological and inertial sensors worn on chest and wrist. For IoT devices, the project created RemedIoT that uses metadata to enable safe handling of contingencies by suggesting a set of remedial actions that can safely provide the same level of utility.

For standardization, the mProv project developed a functional minimal metadata specification for streaming datastreams that is easily generated and tied to data. A new IEEE P1752 Working group (WG) was established that has already published IEEE Std 1752.1TM-2021 IEEE Standard for Open Mobile Health Data—Representation of Metadata, Sleep, and Physical Activity Measures. 

To ensure the matching of streaming data to the metadata, the project developed a new metadata API protocol that requires any client uploading data to first register the datastream by sending its metadata to the cloud where a unique upload route is created to accept the data.  This multi-step validation process prior to storing any streaming data received from smartphones and wearables reduces the amount of corrupt or invalid data which makes the provenance server’s job easier and more generally, reduce the effort needed for researchers utilizing these datasets.

mProv’s metadata infrastructure and API was used to collect an open dataset to seed provenance work. The project developed smartwatch and smartphone apps (called MOODS) to collect wearable sensor data with sensor-triggered stress and stressor annotations from 100+ individuals who were willing to donate their sensor data for research use without restriction. The still ongoing MOODS study has already resulted in one of the largest dataset of its kind with 52,412 hours of wearable sensor (PPG) data and 9,225 stressor reports, consisting of 1,296 unique stressor entries that is to be released publicly upon study completion, data curation, and privacy audit.

To enhance privacy preservation, the project developed mSieve to allow data contributing users to replace sensitive data segments with plausible deniability. As an alternative, the project also developed a wearable data synthesizer called SenseGen that generates synthetic data with similar attributes but without revealing the actual real-life data. To help researchers automatically create easily readable privacy policies, the project developed mPolicy, a privacy policy language, and a library called privLibthat allows for enforcement of policies and attaching new policies to the various types of derived data. The project also created an electronic consent form generator as a web service to assist the study designer by providing boilerplate text for typical privacy sections in a consent form. 

For dissemination, in addition to publications, major software developed for the project have been released publicly on GitHub with associated tutorials as Google Colab. Methods and tools from the project have also been integrated in course materials (e.g., in UPenn’s CIS 5450).


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Santosh Kumar
